pages.text: While once closely connected with ours (see $(l:concepts/wild_magic)My History of Wild Magic$()), the Fey is an entirely separate world. Much power can be found there, and it is this that empowers many of the great creatures from the Fey.$(br2)Old documents speak of trade and passage between worlds, but it is unclear how this was accomplished, and how much travel and trade occurred.

There are many rumours and stories that suggest things in our world originally came from the Fey, but there is also evidence against this.$(br2)For Example, $(l:herbs/pereskia)Pereskia$() is often called 'fairy flower', but while it may delight such creatures, it is simply a flower that blossomed with wild magic.$(br2)Those delightful plant-creatures, Sprouts, on the other hand, seem to be descendants of the Fey.

It is essential to keep an open mind. When presented with something 'from the Fey', you should rightfully question it.$(br2)When told a spell derives 'from the Fey', remember wild magic was great before the Order of Druids even existed.$(br2)While questioning, however, remember perhaps, like sprouts, there ARE other Fey-born things in our world.

pages.name: The Sprout
pages.text: A common example of sentient plant.
